<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
STOCKS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/17/hertz-pulls-controversial-stock-offering?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
SEC Pulls the Emergency Brake on Hertz
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Hertz meme" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNDExL2hlcnR6LnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Toby Howell</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, Hertz <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/06/17/hertz-halts-plan-to-sell-500-million-in-shares-after-sec-review.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">suspended its plan</a> to sell up to $500 million in stock in a last-ditch effort to raise money. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What happened? </strong>Someone at the SEC got mad they didn’t get to upgrade their Ford Focus. Earlier in the day, Hertz halted trading of its stock after the regulator said it would investigate the bankrupt rental car company’s controversial proposal.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory: </strong>Hertz’s business has crumbled ever since, well...you know. It filed for bankruptcy on May 22, and four days later its stock hit a low of $0.40. After that? Chaos.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Hertz’s stock went ballistic, surging over 1,400% to a high of more than $6 at one point on June 8.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Because to amateur investors with nothing else to do, bankruptcy = opportunity. </span><span><a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-06-09/hundreds-of-thousands-tiny-investors-swarm-to-insolvency-stocks?sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">96,000 Robinhood traders</a></span><span> bought Hertz shares over the span of one week. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Mind you, as all this was going on Hertz was <em>still</em> bankrupt, meaning it didn't have enough assets to satisfy its debt obligations (and Hertz was almost $19 billion in debt). With a turnaround unlikely... </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Hertz busted out the spare tire</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In its now-kibashed plan to sell stock, Hertz wrote, “we expect that common stock holders would not receive a recovery through any plan unless the holders of more senior claims and interests...are paid in full.”</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Translation: </strong></span><span>Even if Hertz emerged from bankruptcy, the common stock it planned to issue would almost certainly </span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/06/15/hertz-says-it-expects-stockholders-to-lose-all-their-money-in-filing-for-selling-more-stock.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">end up worthless</a></span><span>.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>And worthless stock is exactly what it sounds like. “It is incredibly creative and they get props for that, but I wouldn’t buy those shares,” Nancy Rapoport, a professor at UNLV’s William S. Boyd School of Law, told Bloomberg.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> From the sudden deterioration of its core business to casual traders’ infatuation with its stock, Hertz embodies the bizarro-world of the coronavirus pandemic. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
BRANDING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/17/aunt-jemima-uncle-bens-owners-rethink-offensive-brands?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Brands on Defense Over Offensive Imagery
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The U.S.’ current reckoning with racial injustice has led some companies to remove racist imagery from their brand names and packaging.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">In the pantry</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Aunt Jemima owner Quaker Oats (itself a PepsiCo subsidiary) <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/17/business/aunt-jemima-racial-stereotype.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">said</a> it would change the syrup and pancake mix brand’s packaging this fall and decide on a new name shortly after. The decision followed a wave of social media posts highlighting the 131-year-old brand’s roots in slavery-era stereotypes—the name Aunt Jemima comes from a song in a minstrel show. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Then, food and candy bigwig Mars said it would “reevaluate” its Uncle Ben’s rice brand. “Now is the right time to evolve the Uncle Ben’s brand, including its visual brand identity, which we will do,” it said in a statement. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">In the locker room</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Critics from Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez to former offensive lineman Tre Johnson have used this moment to <a href="https://www.nbcwashington.com/news/sports/redskins/racial-justice-protests-revive-debate-over-washington-redskins-name/2330544/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">renew calls</a> for the NFL’s Washington Redskins to change their name. Earlier this spring, Land O'Lakes said it would <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/17/business/land-o-lakes-butter.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">remove</a> the image of a Native American woman from its products.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SOCIAL MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/17/twitter-rolls-audio-tweet-feature?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Introducing Twitter for Your Ears
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Twitter voice" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNDA3L3R3aXR0ZXJfdm9pY2UuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In the days of yore, the word “tweet” actually referred to a noise made by birds. Now, Twitter is <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2020/6/17/21294481/twitter-audio-tweets-now-available-iphone-ios?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">bringing the term back</a> to its aural origins—by debuting an option to tweet in audio form. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The feature is currently available to a limited group of iOS users, but will roll out to all users over the coming weeks. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Twitter says the goal is to add “conversational nuances” that are lost in text-based exchanges—as if “covfefe” wasn’t clear enough. But while audio may convey more nuance, it’s much harder to regulate than text. Moderators have to locate the potentially offensive portion of an audio file. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Speaking of moderation…</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The DOJ dropped a proposal yesterday to snatch tech’s legal immunity out from under it. It’s a broader version of the <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/28/trump-issues-executive-order-social-media-companies.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">executive order</a> President Trump issued last month, and would hold companies such as Twitter and Facebook liable for illegal activity that’s facilitated on their platforms.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That would be a massive blow...but Trump and the DOJ need Congress’s support to pass that kind of legislation.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">
<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F06%2F17%2Ftwitter-rolls-audio-tweet-feature" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">
<img alt="" style="display: inline-block; width: 25px" width="25" src="https://media.sailthru.com/5z8/1k4/4/2/5e865734bf6f7.jpg">
</a><span>  </span>
<a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=The+goal+is+to+add+%E2%80%9Cconversational+nuances%E2%80%9D+that+are+lost+in+text-based+exchanges&url=https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/17/twitter-rolls-audio-tweet-feature&via=MorningBrew" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">

<img alt="" style="display: inline-block; width: 25px" width="25" src="https://media.sailthru.com/5z8/1k4/4/2/5e86576e04837.jpg">
</a><span>  </span>

<img alt="" style="display: inline-block; width: 25px" width="25" src="https://media.sailthru.com/5z8/1k4/4/2/5e8657887c532.jpg">
</a>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPONSORED BY WEWORK
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="#" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Making the Office Work for You
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N984048.3407870MORNINGBREW/B24157651.273266516;dc_trk_aid=469909632;dc_trk_cid=132385868;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="WeWork" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL3BsYWNlbWVudC9pbWFnZXMvNzU0LzE1OTIyMzU1NjgtQ2l0eVdvcmxkX0JyYW5kZWRDb250ZW50X1ByaW1hcnlfV2VXb3JrLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6ImNvbWV0LW1vcm5pbmdicmV3IiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Many companies have been figuring out just <em>how </em>to get their teams back to work.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N984048.3407870MORNINGBREW/B24157651.273266516;dc_trk_aid=469909632;dc_trk_cid=132385868;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N984048.3407870MORNINGBREW/B24157651.273266516;dc_trk_aid=469909632;dc_trk_cid=132385868;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">So in the third and final part of our office discussion guide with WeWork</a>, we’re digging into the details for bringing your company back to the office.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Whether your company has five employees or 5,000, your old office probably isn’t cut out for the new normal. How are you going to adapt? How will you collaborate in new ways?</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In this piece, we explore some safe ways to get back to the office for all kinds of companies, whether it’s <a href="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N984048.3407870MORNINGBREW/B24157651.273266516;dc_trk_aid=469909632;dc_trk_cid=132385868;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">making a city your campus</a> or <a href="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N984048.3407870MORNINGBREW/B24157651.273266516;dc_trk_aid=469909632;dc_trk_cid=132385868;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">expanding on your work from home strategy</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Take a read of our final office-based article right <a href="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N984048.3407870MORNINGBREW/B24157651.273266516;dc_trk_aid=469909632;dc_trk_cid=132385868;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">here</a>.</p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</th>
</tr>
</table>

</div>
<!-- <![endif]-->


<!--[if !mso ]><! -- -->
<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
COVID-19
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/17/beijing-implements-business-travel-restrictions-following-cluster-new-cases?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Beijing Wants to Stay Second-Wave Free
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As a cluster of new coronavirus cases <a href="https://apnews.com/54374ff841dfd84323a1fb86d1e93180?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">emerges</a> in Beijing, Chinese officials are trying to avoid déjà vu.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>70% of flights departing from Beijing’s two airports were canceled Wednesday.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Schools, entertainment venues, and some bars were shut down. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Retail stores and restaurants are once again requiring customers to wear masks.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Must be a bad outbreak, huh? Not exactly. The government discovered <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/china-tightens-controls-over-beijing-as-coronavirus-infections-spread-11592405179?mod=hp_lead_pos3&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">31 new cases</a> on Tuesday linked to a major food market that supplies the city with fresh produce. More than 100 new cases have been identified over the past week. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>Compared to the U.S., where new COVID-19 cases are rising in many southern states, the Beijing outbreak is tiny. But the Communist Party in China has recently bragged about its coronavirus response compared to Western countries—so authorities are treating any little spark as a potential blaze. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ While we’re here: </strong>NYC is <a href="https://abc7ny.com/cuomo-vs-de-blasio-new-york-city-phase-2-june-22-reopen-nyc/6252213/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">ready</a> to enter “phase 2” of reopening, which includes outdoor dining, on Monday.</p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
CURRENCY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/17/powell-soothes-fears-coin-shortage?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Banks Run Out of Money
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Mario coins" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=603 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/Fd2RnPlhaHVlu/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Mario coins" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/Fd2RnPlhaHVlu/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If we had a nickel for every nickel that U.S. banks have...we wouldn't have very many nickels. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Testifying before a congressional committee about monetary policy yesterday, Fed Chair Jerome Powell brought up an interesting piece of news: U.S. banks are facing a <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-fed-powell-coins/americans-face-new-coranavirus-challenge-a-shortage-of-coins-idUSKBN23O36U?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">coin shortage</a>. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Penny for your thoughts, Jerome?</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">“The flow of coins through the economy has kind of stopped,” Powell said.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>With retail stores across the country closed, there just aren't very many places for consumers to exchange physical money.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Exacerbating the shortage, the U.S. Mint decreased coin production to help keep its employees safe from the virus. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Powell assured the committee that he’s aware of the issue and it’s being addressed. “We all don’t want to wake up to headlines in the near future such as ‘Banks run out of money,’” he said.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/grimacing-face_1f62c.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""></p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FROM THE CREW
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/17/brews-bookshelf-pride-month?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Brew's Bookshelf
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="books" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC82ODIvYnJld19zX2Jvb2tzaGVsZi5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><em>Every other Thursday, we’re bringing you our favorite business-related reads. In honor of Pride Month, this week’s selection explores the history of the LGBTQ movement and its impact on businesses. </em></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Activism: </strong><a href="https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/609115/the-queering-of-corporate-america-by-carlos-a-ball/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>The Queering of Corporate America</em></a> by Carlos Ball traces a half-century of LGBTQ activism that's not only shaped how big businesses treat queer communities, but turned many into allies and advocates.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Memoir: </strong><a href="https://www.harpercollins.com/9780062316974/the-glass-closet/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>The Glass Closet</em></a> by Lord John Browne tells the former BP CEO’s story of coming out and the challenges LGBTQ employees face in the workplace.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">History:</strong> <a href="https://www.lillianfaderman.net/2013/03/the-gay-revolution.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>The Gay Revolution</em></a><em> </em>by Lillian Faderman traces the fight for LGBTQ civil rights from the 1950s to the 2010s, exploring protests, the impact of the AIDS epidemic, and the fight for marriage equality. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Got another recommendation for us? <a href="https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/O2tX0X?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Share it here</a>.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">
<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F06%2F17%2Fbrews-bookshelf-pride-month" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">
<img alt="" style="display: inline-block; width: 25px" width="25" src="https://media.sailthru.com/5z8/1k4/4/2/5e865734bf6f7.jpg">

width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNDExL2hlcnR6LnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eToby Howell\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, Hertz \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/06/17/hertz-halts-plan-to-sell-500-million-in-shares-after-sec-review.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esuspended its plan\u003c/a\u003e to sell up to $500 million in stock in a last-ditch effort to raise money. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat happened? \u003c/strong\u003eSomeone at the SEC got mad they didn’t get to upgrade their Ford Focus. Earlier in the day, Hertz halted trading of its stock after the regulator said it would investigate the bankrupt rental car company’s controversial proposal.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory: \u003c/strong\u003eHertz’s business has crumbled ever since, well...you know. It filed for bankruptcy on May 22, and four days later its stock hit a low of $0.40. After that? Chaos.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHertz’s stock went ballistic, surging over 1,400% to a high of more than $6 at one point on June 8.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eBecause to amateur investors with nothing else to do, bankruptcy = opportunity. \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-06-09/hundreds-of-thousands-tiny-investors-swarm-to-insolvency-stocks?sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e96,000 Robinhood traders\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e bought Hertz shares over the span of one week. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eMind you, as all this was going on Hertz was \u003cem\u003estill\u003c/em\u003e bankrupt, meaning it didn't have enough assets to satisfy its debt obligations (and Hertz was almost $19 billion in debt). With a turnaround unlikely... \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eHertz busted out the spare tire\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn its now-kibashed plan to sell stock, Hertz wrote, “we expect that common stock holders would not receive a recovery through any plan unless the holders of more senior claims and interests...are paid in full.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eTranslation: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eEven if Hertz emerged from bankruptcy, the common stock it planned to issue would almost certainly \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/06/15/hertz-says-it-expects-stockholders-to-lose-all-their-money-in-filing-for-selling-more-stock.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eend up worthless\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAnd worthless stock is exactly what it sounds like. “It is incredibly creative and they get props for that, but I wouldn’t buy those shares,” Nancy Rapoport, a professor at UNLV’s William S. Boyd School of Law, told Bloomberg.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line:\u003c/strong\u003e From the sudden deterioration of its core business to casual traders’ infatuation with its stock, Hertz embodies the bizarro-world of the coronavirus pandemic. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe U.S.’ current reckoning with racial injustice has led some companies to remove racist imagery from their brand names and packaging.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eIn the pantry\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAunt Jemima owner Quaker Oats (itself a PepsiCo subsidiary) \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/17/business/aunt-jemima-racial-stereotype.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esaid\u003c/a\u003e it would change the syrup and pancake mix brand’s packaging this fall and decide on a new name shortly after. The decision followed a wave of social media posts highlighting the 131-year-old brand’s roots in slavery-era stereotypes—the name Aunt Jemima comes from a song in a minstrel show. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThen, food and candy bigwig Mars said it would “reevaluate” its Uncle Ben’s rice brand. “Now is the right time to evolve the Uncle Ben’s brand, including its visual brand identity, which we will do,” it said in a statement. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eIn the locker room\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eCritics from Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez to former offensive lineman Tre Johnson have used this moment to \u003ca href=\"https://www.nbcwashington.com/news/sports/redskins/racial-justice-protests-revive-debate-over-washington-redskins-name/2330544/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erenew calls\u003c/a\u003e for the NFL’s Washington Redskins to change their name. Earlier this spring, Land O'Lakes said it would \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/17/business/land-o-lakes-butter.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eremove\u003c/a\u003e the image of a Native American woman from its products.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn the days of yore, the word “tweet” actually referred to a noise made by birds. Now, Twitter is \u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2020/6/17/21294481/twitter-audio-tweets-now-available-iphone-ios?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebringing the term back\u003c/a\u003e to its aural origins—by debuting an option to tweet in audio form. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe feature is currently available to a limited group of iOS users, but will roll out to all users over the coming weeks. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eTwitter says the goal is to add “conversational nuances” that are lost in text-based exchanges—as if “covfefe” wasn’t clear enough. But while audio may convey more nuance, it’s much harder to regulate than text. Moderators have to locate the potentially offensive portion of an audio file. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eSpeaking of moderation…\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe DOJ dropped a proposal yesterday to snatch tech’s legal immunity out from under it. It’s a broader version of the \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/28/trump-issues-executive-order-social-media-companies.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eexecutive order\u003c/a\u003e President Trump issued last month, and would hold companies such as Twitter and Facebook liable for illegal activity that’s facilitated on their platforms.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThat would be a massive blow...but Trump and the DOJ need Congress’s support to pass that kind of legislation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAs a cluster of new coronavirus cases \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/54374ff841dfd84323a1fb86d1e93180?utm_source=morning_brew\"
